summary: This is an email exchange between prosecutors and defense attorney Christian Everdell regarding pre-trial legal issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The prosecution inquires about potential defense strategies, specifically whether Maxwell intends to offer expert evidence on mental condition or argue she was a victim of Jeffrey Epstein's abuse.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with prosecutors about pre-trial motions and notice requirements under Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and convicted sex offender; referenced as the alleged perpetrator whose abuse Maxwell's defense might argue she was a victim of.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case; the email discusses potential defense strategies regarding her mental condition and whether she was a victim of Epstein.

connections.description: Everdell is Maxwell's defense attorney, as indicated by his correspondence with prosecutors about her defense strategy.
The prosecution references the defense potentially arguing Maxwell was a victim of Epstein's abuse, indicating their prior association.

events.title: Prosecution-Defense Call
events.description: A call between prosecutors and defense attorney Christian Everdell discussing Rule 412 motion briefing schedule and Rule 12.2 notice requirements.

events.title: Prosecution Inquiry on Defense Strategy
events.description: Prosecutors send email asking defense to clarify if they intend to offer expert evidence on Maxwell's mental condition or argue she was a victim of Epstein's abuse.

keyFacts: Prosecutors are inquiring whether Ghislaine Maxwell's defense intends to argue she was a victim of Jeffrey Epstein's abuse.
Prosecutors consider any expert evidence relating to Maxwell's mental condition and bearing on guilt to be waived under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 12.2.
The defense had requested an earlier briefing schedule for a Rule 412 motion, but prosecutors believe the standard timeline is appropriate given recent receipt of voluminous discovery materials.
The email exchange reveals active pre-trial litigation strategy discussions between prosecution and defense ahead of Maxwell's trial.
